awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Highly Stable Nanoparticle-Doped Metal-Organic Frameworks for Applications in Water Purification
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at the home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The award to Virginia Union University will seek to determine the best synthetic protocols to analyze nanoparticle-doped meal-organic framework (NP@MOFs) systems for their water filtration and sanitation properties and to make structural modifications of these material based on observed performance. 

The proposed work explores the simultaneous elimination of biological and chemical contaminants in water through one composite system. The objectives are to investigate the impact of the encapsulation of metal nanoparticles inside water stable MOFs on water purification properties and determine the stability and recyclability of new and existing NP@MOF systems when used for water purification applications. The study will be done in four phases with efforts to offer a system which allows minimal diffusion of doped nanoparticles in the filtration process. The broader impacts of the proposed work will be the application of the proposed NP@MOF systems into an advanced mechanism for water filtration which is essential in underdeveloped civilizations and undeserved citizenry. Moreover, the proposed work will enhance the infrastructure of research at VUU, while creating opportunities and access to underrepresented students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we sought to determine the best synthetic protocols for nanoparticle-doped metal-organic frameworks, to analyze these materials for their water filtration and sanitation properties and to make structural modification of these materials based on their performance. Proposed activities were to take place in four major phases. Phase 1 involved the establishment of synthetic protocols for three MOFs (UiO-66, MIL-101, and ZIF-8) and three NPs (copper, silver, and gold) known to exhibit antimicrobial properties. Phase 2 will involve the investigation of the molecular sieving capabilities of MOFs particularly for the most common organics, pharmaceutical, and inorganic (lead, arsenic, mercury, etc.) contaminants in water. Phase 2 will also include investigations into the antibacterial properties of NPs. Biological targets will include commonly studied bacterial contaminants such as Escherichia coli (E. coli), Staphylococcus aureus (s. Aureus), and Vibrio cholerae (V. cholerae). Phase 3 entails the doping process, i.e. examining the best methods of encapsulating nanoparticles into the MOF pores. Phase 4 will involve the study of these NP@MOF systems for their antibacterial and contaminant sieving properties.

The major goal which is to establish a new research program was completed as well as the engagement of approximately 15 undergraduate students in research as described in the proposal and compensated for their time of effort. Among these, most have graduated and three are rising seniors.

Major activities included:

  1. engagement of undergraduate students in research on synthesis of MOFs, specifically UiO-66 and ZIF-8; synthesis of silver and copper nanoparticles, organic dye (methylene blue)/pharmaceutical product (curcumin) adsorption performance; and installation and training on essential equipment, including gas volumetric analyzer, powder x-ray diffraction, UV-Vis and atomic absorption spectrophotometer, and scanning electron microscopy to analyze samples.
  2. Establishment of a community of undergraduate chemistry majors, refer to as Persisting chemistry Scholars led by two senior students designated as St Elmo Brady Scholar and Marie M Daly Scholar.
  3. Reporting of research progress at undergraduate research symposium at Virginia State University and the Virginia Section of the American Chemical Society Undergraduate Research Poster Session

As of now, results have only been communicated through NSF PI/PD meetings and undergraduate poster sessions, national ACS meetings and the 2022 NOBCChE annual meeting. Multiple instruments were procured including, powder x-ray diffraction, gas sorption analyzer, and sample prep station to establish a robust research program which is now thriving. The grant provided resources for equipment for research that could be used for classes as well. It also provided funding for undergraduate research and academic support for participants which has benefit students at Virginia Union University and Virgnia State University over the life of the grant. A perspective manuscript is currently in preparation in collaboration with other recipients of the Research Initiation Award on the experience of starting new chemistry research programs at HBCU's during COVID. Publications detailing the findings related to metal ion and molecular sieving investigations are anticipated to be published by the end of 2024.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2024
Modified by: Karl T Jackson
